elements.content: A series of six coordination polymers, namely, [Cd1.5(L)] n (1), [Cd1.5(L)­(bpp)] n (2), {[Cd1.5(L)­(p-bix)]­·H2O} n (3), [Cd1.5(L)­(m-bix)] n (4), {[Cd1.5(L)­(dpa)3­(H2O)]­·2H2O} n (5), and {[Cd1.5(L)­(bpbd)2.5]­·2H2O} n (6) (Na3L = (S)-(−)-5-(1-carboxy-ethoxymethyl)-isophthalic acid trisodium salt), have been hydrothermally synthesized through the reaction of Na3L with divalent cadmium salts with or without the presence of ancillary nitrogen ligands (bpp = 1,3-bi(4-pyridyl)­propane, p-bix = 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)­benzene, m-bix = 1,3-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)­benzene, dpa = 4,4′-dipyridylamine, bpbd = 2,3-bis(4′-pyridyl)-2,3-butanediol)). Complex 1 is a three-dimensional (3D) framework and displays a (4,8)-connected framework with {412·612·84}{46}2 (flu) topology. 2 features a 3D architecture too, in which the one-dimensional (1D) (Cd-bpp) n helical chains are alternately arranged in a right- and left-handed sequence. Complex 3 exhibits a homochiral 3D framework and is a new (3,8)-connected net with a Schläfli symbol of {4·5·6}2­{42·56·618·7·8} topology. Complex 4 bears a homochiral layered structure, which is united together to generate a 3D supramolecular structure through interlayer C–H···O and C–H···π interactions. Interlayer C–H···π and N–H···N interactions led layered complex 5 to a 3D supramolecular architecture. Complex 6 shows a new (3,5,6)-connected net with a Schläfli symbol of {4·62}2­{42·610·82·10}­{42·66·82}2 topology. Complexes 3 and 4 crystallize in the chiral C2 space group, and their circular dichroism spectra exhibit obvious positive or negative Cotton effects. Moreover, 3 and 4 are second-harmonic generation (SHG) active, and the SHG efficiency is 0.5 and 0.4 times as much as that of urea, respectively.

elements.content: Six coordination polymers supported by a chiral aromatic polycarboxylate ligand have been obtained. Complexes 1, 2, 5, and 6 display achiral architectures, while 3 and 4 exhibit homochiral structures. The circular dichroism spectra of 3 and 4 exhibit obvious Cotton effects, and the second-harmonic generation efficiency is 0.5 and 0.4 times as much as that of urea, respectively.

elements.content: Over the past few decades, the self-assembly process driven by coordination chemistry has generated many fascinating structures from discrete molecular cages to three-dimensional (3D) porous frameworks. Because of their tunable and porous nature, coordination polymers show desired properties in applications such as gas storage, catalysis, and molecular sensing.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Over the past few decades, the self-assembly process driven by coordination chemistry has generated many fascinating structures from discrete molecular cages to three-dimensional (3D) porous frameworks. Because of their tunable and porous nature, coordination polymers show desired properties in applications such as gas storage, catalysis, and molecular sensing.

elements.content: Ongoing research in our laboratory has been directed toward the design and synthesis of new carboxylate-based ligands. The geometric orientation of carboxylate donors and various carboxylate binding modes provide a plethora of diverse structural topologies. Among the reported metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) constructed from the aromatic multicarboxylic ligands, architectures based on isophthalic acid ligands always display large cagelike structures.

elements.content: Chirality is one of the fundamental phenomena in nature, which has potential applications in asymmetric catalysis, chiral separations, and the like, so that many efforts have been devoted to the synthesis and utilization of artificial chiral architectures. Incorporating chiral functional groups into an organic ligand is a good choice to construct chiral coordination polymers. Moreover, chiral metal–organic coordination polymers based on pure chiral polypyridyl groups and polycarboxylate groups have been studied recently. However, chiral metal–organic coordination polymers assembled from pure chiral aromatic polycarboxylate group ligands with multinitrogen heterocycle auxiliary organic ligands remain largely unexplored so far.

elements.content: With the above consideration, a new chiral triangular ligand (S)-(−)-5-(1-carboxy-ethoxymethyl)-isophthalic acid trisodium salt ((S)-Na3L, as shown in ) has been synthesized and selected to construct coordination architectures. The Na3L ligand possesses the following advantages: (a) It is a tripodal ligand with one flexible carboxylate group and two rigid carboxylate groups which may be efficient to construct interesting structures. (b) The enantiomerically pure organic spacer (L3–) provides the possibility for the syntheses of homochiral metal–organic frameworks. (c) The multiple bridging modes of carboxyl moieties have great superiority in the construction of fascinating coordination polymers, especially with high dimensionalities.

(b) The enantiomerically pure organic spacer (L3-) provides the possibility for the syntheses of homochiral metal-organic frameworks. (c) The multiple bridging modes of carboxyl moieties have great superiority in the construction of fascinating coordination polymers, especially with high dimensionalities.

elements.content: In this work, we have engaged in the research of coordination polymers based on the chiral ligand Na3L with a d10 metal center (Cd) to understand the coordination chemistry of Na3L and prepare new materials with interesting structural topology and excellent photoluminescent properties. Meanwhile, the mixed-ligands strategy, incorporating ancillary nitrogen colinkers with different lengths and rigidness/flexibility (), has proven to be successful in the creation of various coordination polymers. Herein, we present six metal–organic coordination polymers: [Cd1.5(L)] n (1), [Cd1.5(L)­(bpp)] n (2), {[Cd1.5(L)­(p-bix)]­·H2O} n (3), [Cd1.5(L)­(m-bix)] n (4), {[Cd1.5(L)­(dpa)3­(H2O)]­·2H2O} n (5), and {[Cd1.5(L)­(bpbd)2.5]·2H2O} n (6) (bpp = 1,3-bi(4-pyridyl)­propane, p-bix = 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)­benzene, m-bix = 1,3-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)­benzene, dpa = 4,4′-dipyridylamine, bpbd = 2,3-bis(4′-pyridyl)-2,3-butanediol)), in which the L3– ligand displays varied coordination modes (). Complexes 3 and 4 are homochiral, whereas complexes 1, 2, 5, and 6 are achiral. 3 and 4 crystallize in the chiral C2 space group, and their solid-state circular dichroism spectra and nonlinear optical properties are investigated.
elements.clean_text: In this work, we have engaged in the research of coordination polymers based on the chiral ligand Na3L with a d10 metal center (Cd) to understand the coordination chemistry of Na3L and prepare new materials with interesting structural topology and excellent photoluminescent properties. Meanwhile, the mixed-ligands strategy, incorporating ancillary nitrogen colinkers with different lengths and rigidness/flexibility (), has proven to be successful in the creation of various coordination polymers. Herein, we present six metal-organic coordination polymers: [Cd1.5(L)] n  (1), [Cd1.5(L)(bpp)] n  (2), {[Cd1.5(L)(p-bix)]⋅H2O} n  (3), [Cd1.5(L)(m-bix)] n  (4), {[Cd1.5(L)(dpa)3(H2O)]⋅2H2O} n  (5), and {[Cd1.5(L)(bpbd)2.5]⋅2H2O} n  (6) (bpp = 1,3-bi(4-pyridyl)propane, p-bix = 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene, m-bix = 1,3-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene, dpa = 4,4'-dipyridylamine, bpbd = 2,3-bis(4'-pyridyl)-2,3-butanediol)), in which the L3- ligand displays varied coordination modes (). Complexes 3 and 4 are homochiral, whereas complexes 1, 2, 5, and 6 are achiral. 3 and 4 crystallize in the chiral C2 space group, and their solid-state circular dichroism spectra and nonlinear optical properties are investigated.

elements.content: All other starting materials were of analytical grade and obtained from commercial sources without further purification. Elemental analysis for C, H, and N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range from 4000 to 400 cm–1 on a Bruker VECTOR 22 spectrometer. Thermal analyses were performed on a SDT 2960 thermal analyzer from room temperature to 800 °C at a heating rate of 20 °C/min under nitrogen flow. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on a Rigaku D/Max-2500PC diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) over the 2θ range of 5–50° with a scan speed of 5°/min at room temperature. Circular dichroism (CD) spectra of solid samples were recorded at room temperature with a MOS-450 spectrometer (KBr pellets). The second-order nonlinear optical intensity was approximately estimated by measuring microcrystalline samples relative to urea. A pulsed Q-switched Nd:YAG laser at a wavelength of 1064 nm was used to generate a second-harmonic generation (SHG) signal from powder samples. The backscattered SHG light was collected by a spherical concave mirror and passed through a filter that transmits only 532 nm radiation. Luminescence spectra for the solid samples were recorded on a Hitachi 850 fluorescence spectrophotometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

All other starting materials were of analytical grade and obtained from commercial sources without further purification. Elemental analysis for C, H, and N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range from 4000 to 400 cm-1 on a Bruker VECTOR 22 spectrometer. Thermal analyses were performed on a SDT 2960 thermal analyzer from room temperature to 800 °C at a heating rate of 20 °C/min under nitrogen flow. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on a Rigaku D/Max-2500PC diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) over the 2θ range of 5-50° with a scan speed of 5°/min at room temperature. Circular dichroism (CD) spectra of solid samples were recorded at room temperature with a MOS-450 spectrometer (KBr pellets). The second-order nonlinear optical intensity was approximately estimated by measuring microcrystalline samples relative to urea. A pulsed Q-switched Nd:YAG laser at a wavelength of 1064 nm was used to generate a second-harmonic generation (SHG) signal from powder samples. The backscattered SHG light was collected by a spherical concave mirror and passed through a filter that transmits only 532 nm radiation. Luminescence spectra for the solid samples were recorded on a Hitachi 850 fluorescence spectrophotometer.

elements.content: The ligand (S)-(−)-5-(1-carboxy-ethoxymethyl)-isophthalic acid trisodium salt (Na3L) was synthesized by reaction of 5-bromomethyl-isophthalic acid dimethyl ester with methyl (s)-(−)-lactate (Scheme ). A mixture of 5-bromomethyl-isophthalic acid dimethyl ester (1.43 g, 5 mmol) and (s)-(−)-lactate (1.0 mL, 10 mmol), and Ag2O (1.16 g, 5 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (20 mL) was stirred for 48 h at rt. After filtration, the solution was evaporated under reduced pressure, and the residue was chromatographed on silica gel with CH2Cl2. The ester was dissolved in 15 mL of methanol with stoichiometric CH3ONa and refluxed until the solution turned clear. The reaction mixture was then removed by evaporation, and the resulting off-white solid Na3L was dried under vacuum overnight. Yield: 1.25 g, 75%. Anal. Calcd for C12H9O7Na3 (%): C, 43.13; H, 2.71; found: C, 44.01; H, 2.30. 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO): 8.36 (s, 1H), 8.20 (d, 1H), 7.92 (d, 1H), 4.33 (m, 1H), 3.81 (m, 2H), 1.29(d, 3H). IR/cm–1 (KBr): 3423(vs), 1593(s), 1368(m), 1246(w), 1116(w), 784(w), 721(w).

Synthesis

Synthesis of Na3L

The ligand (S)-(-)-5-(1-carboxy-ethoxymethyl)-isophthalic acid trisodium salt (Na3L) was synthesized by reaction of 5-bromomethyl-isophthalic acid dimethyl ester with methyl (s)-(-)-lactate (Scheme ). A mixture of 5-bromomethyl-isophthalic acid dimethyl ester (1.43 g, 5 mmol) and (s)-(-)-lactate (1.0 mL, 10 mmol), and Ag2O (1.16 g, 5 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (20 mL) was stirred for 48 h at rt. After filtration, the solution was evaporated under reduced pressure, and the residue was chromatographed on silica gel with CH2Cl2. The ester was dissolved in 15 mL of methanol with stoichiometric CH3ONa and refluxed until the solution turned clear. The reaction mixture was then removed by evaporation, and the resulting off-white solid Na3L was dried under vacuum overnight. Yield: 1.25 g, 75%. Anal. Calcd for C12H9O7Na3 (%): C, 43.13; H, 2.71; found: C, 44.01; H, 2.30. 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO): 8.36 (s, 1H), 8.20 (d, 1H), 7.92 (d, 1H), 4.33 (m, 1H), 3.81 (m, 2H), 1.29(d, 3H). IR/cm-1 (KBr): 3423(vs), 1593(s), 1368(m), 1246(w), 1116(w), 784(w), 721(w).

elements.content: Complex 1 was synthesized hydrothermally in a Teflon-lined stainless steel container by heating a mixture of (S)-Na3L (0.0167 g, 0.05 mmol) and Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (0.0308 g, 0.10 mmol) in 6 mL of distilled water at 130 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature. Colorless block crystals of 1 were collected and washed with water. Yield: 57% based on cadmium. Anal. Calcd for C24H18Cd3O14 (%): C, 33.23; H, 2.09. Found: C, 33.32; H, 2.21. IR/cm–1 (KBr): 3423(s), 1604(s), 1556(vs), 1452(s), 1377(vs), 1112(m), 1062(w), 1018(w), 909(w), 776(m), 736(m).

elements.content: Single crystals suitable for X-ray analyses were used for intensity data collection on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature using the ω-scan technique. Lorentz polarization and absorption corrections were applied. The structures were solved by direct methods with SHELXS-97 and refined with the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXL-97 program. Anisotropic thermal parameters were assigned to all non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms of the coordinated water molecules and ligands were included in the structure factor calculation at idealized positions by using a riding model and refined isotropically. Analytical expressions of neutral atom scattering factors were employed, and anomalous dispersion corrections were incorporated. The crystallographic data and selected bond lengths and angles for complexes 1–6 are listed in Table and Table S1, . The topological analysis and some diagrams were produced using the TOPOS program.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Single crystals suitable for X-ray analyses were used for intensity data collection on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature using the ω-scan technique. Lorentz polarization and absorption corrections were applied. The structures were solved by direct methods with SHELXS-97 and refined with the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXL-97 program. Anisotropic thermal parameters were assigned to all non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms of the coordinated water molecules and ligands were included in the structure factor calculation at idealized positions by using a riding model and refined isotropically. Analytical expressions of neutral atom scattering factors were employed, and anomalous dispersion corrections were incorporated. The crystallographic data and selected bond lengths and angles for complexes 1-6 are listed in Table  and Table S1, . The topological analysis and some diagrams were produced using the TOPOS program.

The results of X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that complex 1 crystallizes in monoclinic P21/c space group (Table ) with a 3D coordination framework. The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of one and a half crystallographically independent Cd atoms (Cd1 and Cd2), and one L3– ligand, among which, the site occupancy of Cd2 is 0.5. Each L3– anion acts as a μ7-bridge to link seven Cd(II) ions through its three carboxylate groups, and the etheric oxygen atom and the coordination mode of μ7-η2: η2: η3 for L3– is found (). As depicted in Figure a, the Cd1 center is six coordinated by six oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O3B, O5D, O6D, and O6E) from four different L3– ligands to form a distorted octahedron. Cd2 is six-coordinated by six oxygen atoms (O1, O1A, O4B, O4C, O7E, and O7F) from six separate L3– ligands, and the Cd–O lengths are in the range of 2.189(9)–2.525(9) Å () and all in the reasonable range. Each Cd2 ion bridges two Cd1 ions by coordinating with O atoms from carboxylate group at C1, C2, and C11 to form a trimetallic subunit (Figure a). Within the trimetallic subunit, the intermetallic distance of Cd1···Cd2 is 3.741(3) Å. The trimetallic subunits are connected by carboxylate groups from L3– ligands to form a one-dimensional (1D) inorganic chain structure along the a-axis, as shown in Figure b. In the crystal structure of complex 1, CdII centers are connected through L3– ligands to give a 3D structure. If we take no account of Cd1, Cd2 centers coordinate with L3– ligands to give rise to a layer structure (Figure c). Moreover, these achiral sheets are further extended via Cd1 coordinate with O5 and O6 atoms from L3– ligands into a 3D framework (Figure d).

The results of X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that complex 1 crystallizes in monoclinic P21/c space group (Table ) with a 3D coordination framework. The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of one and a half crystallographically independent Cd atoms (Cd1 and Cd2), and one L3- ligand, among which, the site occupancy of Cd2 is 0.5. elements.content: To better understand the complicated 3D structure of 1, topological analysis is carried out. The above-mentioned trimetallic subunit can be viewed as a eight-connected node since it links eight L3– ligands, and the L3– ligand can be considered as a four-connector by linking four trimetallic subunits. Such connectivity repeats infinitely to give the 3D framework of 1 as schematically shown in Figure e. According to the simplification principle, the resulting structure of 1 is a binodal (4,8)-connected net with its Point (Schläfli) symbol of {412·612·84}{46}2, which is referred to as flu topology.

elements.content: Complex 2 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c. As shown in Figure a, the asymmetric unit of 2 is composed of one and a half crystallographically independent Cd centers (Cd1 and Cd2), one L3– anion, and one bpp ligand, among which, Cd2 has an occupancy of 0.5. As shown in , the coordination mode of μ6-η2: η2: η2 for L3– is found in complex 2. The L3– ligand acts as a μ6-bridge to link six cadmium ions: the carboxylates at C1 and C2 are both monondentate bridging to one and bidentate chelating to another cadmium ion (μ2-η1:η2); the carboxylate at C11 is monodentate bridging to two cadmium metals (μ2-η1:η1). Cd1 is in pentagonal bipyramid coordination surrounded by two N atoms from two bpp ligands and five O atoms from three carboxylate groups of three different L3– ligands. Cd2 is six-coordinated by six O atoms from six carboxylate groups of six different L3– ligands to form a distorted octahedron. The bond lengths of Cd–O are in the range of 2.197(5)–2.641(4) (Table S1, ).

elements.content: Each Cd2 ion bridges two Cd1 ions by coordinating with O atoms from carboxylate groups at C1, C2, and C11 to form a trimetallic subnuit. Within the trimetallic subunit, the intermetallic distance of Cd1···Cd2 is 3.479 Å (Figure b). The trimetallic subunits are connected by three carboxylate groups from L3– ligands to form into a two-dimensional (2D) double-layer along the ab plane. Consequently, as shown in Figure b, the adjacent double-layers are further linked to 3D network through Cd1 coordinating with N(bpp) atoms, which form into helical chains with right- and left-handed chirality, leading to a 3D network. The screw axes of these helices are all parallel to the b axis, and the pitch is 10.740 Å.

Therefore, the whole 3D framework of 2 can be simplified as a (3,10)-connected net with a point symbol of {43}2{410·634·8}, which is referred to as 3,10T5 (MOF.ttd) topology (Figures c and S2 in ).

The asymmetric unit of 3 is comprised of one and a half crystallographically independent Cd atoms (Cd1 and Cd2, the site occupancy of Cd1 is 0.5), one L3– ligand, one p-bix ligand, and one lattice water molecule, as illustrated in Figure a. Each L3– anion acts as a μ5-bridge to link five Cd(II) ions through its three carboxylate groups and the coordination mode of μ5-η2: η2: η1 for L3– is found in complex 3 (). Cd2 center is surrounded by four oxygen atoms from separate L3– ligands, and two nitrogen atoms from two p-bix ligands. Each Cd1 ion bridges two Cd2 ions by coordinating with O atoms from carboxylate groups at C1 and C2 to form a trimetallic subnuit. Within the trimetallic subunit, the intermetallic distance of Cd1···Cd2 is 3.923 Å (Figure c).

elements.content: In the crystal structure of complex 3, due to the use of chiral ligands, Cd1 centers coordinate with O atoms from carboxyl groups to form an infinite left-handed helical chain, the winding axis corresponds to the b axis and the pitch to the length of 14.625 Å, as shown in Figure b. These helical chains with the same rotation direction are connected to each other to form homochiral helical layers with left-handed screws (Figure S3, ). These helical layers are fused together to yield a 3D coordinated framework via Cd2 centers coordinating with O1 atoms from 1-COO–, O4 atoms from 3-COO–, and O6, O7 atoms from 5-COO– of the adjacent layers, as shown in . In this framework, channels exist along the c direction. There are p-bix ligands in the channel to coordinate with Cd2 atoms to stabilize the 3D framework (Figure c).

elements.content: A single-crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that complex 4 crystallizes in monoclinic system with C2 space group with a Flack parameter of 0.02(3). As shown in Figure a, the asymmetric unit of 4 is composed of one and a half Cd centers (Cd1 and Cd2), one L3– anion, and one m-bix ligand, among which, the site occupancy of Cd1 is 0.5. In the crystal structure of 4, the three carboxylate groups of the L3– ligand connect six CdII ions in three different coordination modes, and the coordination mode of μ6-η1: η2: η3 for L3– is found in complex 4, as shown in . The Cd1 center adopts a distorted octahedral geometry by coordinating to two nitrogen atoms (N2 and N2A) from neighboring m-bix ligands, and four oxygen atoms (O2, O2A, O6C, and O6D) from four different L3– anions. The nitrogen atom (N2A) and oxygen atom (O6D) occupy the axial positions, and the other nitrogen atom (N2) and oxygen atoms (O2, O2A, and O6C) comprise the equatorial plane. The Cd2 center is also six-coordinated to form a distorted octahedral geometry by O1, O3B, O4B, O6D, and O7C from four distinct L3– ligands, N3 from an m-bix ligand. The Cd–O bond lengths fall in the range of 2.272–2.426 Å (Table S1, ). Each Cd1 ion bridges two Cd2 ions by coordinating with O atoms from carboxylate groups at C1 to form a equilateral triangular trimetallic subnuit. Within the trimetallic subunit, the intermetallic distance of Cd1···Cd2 and Cd2···Cd2 is 3.646 Å and 5.702 Å, respectively (Figure d).

elements.content: As shown in Figure c, linkage of L3– anions and CdII cations furnish a chiral 2D Cd-L backbone. It is noteworthy that in the 2D Cd–L backbone of 4, due to the use of chiral ligands, the carboxylates of L3– bridge the Cd1 ions to form a 1D left-handed helical chain running along the b axis with a pitch of 10.257 Å (Figure b). Adjacent left-handed helical chains are connected to give rise to a 2D homochiral helical structure by the connection of Cd1 and Cd2 through L3– ligands. As for m-bix ligand, it adopts the cis-conformation, with both imidazole groups on the same side of the central benzene ring, to coordinate with Cd1 and Cd2 ions to stabilize the 2D Cd–L backbone (Figure c). The cooperative C–H···O hydrogen bonds and C–H···π interactions join the 2D homochiral helical layers into a 3D supramolecular architecture and build the hydrophobic space in this crystal (Figure c and Figure 4d).

elements.content: Complex 5 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅. As shown in Figure a, the asymmetric unit contains one and a half crystallographically independent cadmium ions (Cd1 and Cd2), one L3– ligand, three dpa ligands, one aqua ligand, and two lattice water molecules, among which, Cd2 has an occupancy of 0.5. As shown in , each L3– anion acts as a μ3-bridge to link three Cd(II) ions through its three carboxylate groups, and the coordination mode of μ3-η1: η1: η1 for L3– is found in complex 5. The coordination geometry for the seven-coordinate Cd1 atom is distorted pentagonal-bipyramidal with a long Cd1–O3A (2.694 Å) distance (Figure a). While Cd2 ion is six coordinated by two oxygen atoms (O6 and O6D) from two different L3– ligands, two oxygen atoms (O1W and O1WD) from two aqua ligands, and two nitrogen atoms (N5B and N5C) from two dpya molecules to finish a slightly distorted octahedral coordination geometry. It should be noted that although O3 is not coordinated to Cd1, the bond distance of Cd1···O3 [2.694(3) Å] is shorter than the sum of the van der Walls radii (3.08 Å), which indicates a weak secondary bonding. This phenomenon may contribute to the distortion of the Cd octahedral geometry and result in the variation of coordination environments.

As shown in , each L3- anion acts as a μ3-bridge to link three Cd(II) ions through its three carboxylate groups, and the coordination mode of μ3-η1: η1: η1 for L3- is found in complex 5. The coordination geometry for the seven-coordinate Cd1 atom is distorted pentagonal-bipyramidal with a long Cd1-O3A (2.694 Å) distance (Figure a). While Cd2 ion is six coordinated by two oxygen atoms (O6 and O6D) from two different L3- ligands, two oxygen atoms (O1W and O1WD) from two aqua ligands, and two nitrogen atoms (N5B and N5C) from two dpya molecules to finish a slightly distorted octahedral coordination geometry. It should be noted that although O3 is not coordinated to Cd1, the bond distance of Cd1⋅⋅⋅O3 [2.694(3) Å] is shorter than the sum of the van der Walls radii (3.08 Å), which indicates a weak secondary bonding. This phenomenon may contribute to the distortion of the Cd octahedral geometry and result in the variation of coordination environments.

elements.content: Complex 5 exhibits a 3D supramolecular structure. The Cd1 and Cd2 atoms are first connected together through L3– ligands to give a Cd–L ribbon, as shown in Figure b. The dpa ligands adopt different coordination modes (Figure c): one bridges Cd1 and Cd2 atoms from adjacent ribbons to form a sheet; the other two dpa ligands have their one terminal N atom binding one Cd1 atom, while the other N end is fixed by hydrogen bonding with other dpa ligand (Figure e). In addition, C–H···π interactions exist associated with pyridyl rings of dpa ligands (H-to-centroid distances of 2.91 and 3.12 Å) in the adjacent layers. These C–H···π interactions and N–H···N hydrogen bonding between layers led the 2D layers to a 3D supramolecular architecture (Figure d,e).

elements.content: Complex 6 is a 3D framework with the triclinic space group of P1̅. The asymmetric unit contains one and a half Cd(II) atoms, one L3– ligand, two and a half bpbd ligands, and two lattice water molecules, among which, Cd1 has an occupancy of 0.5. Each L anion acts as a μ3-bridge to link three Cd(II) ions through its three carboxylate groups, and the coordination mode of μ3-η1: η1: η1 for L3– is found in complex 6 (). As depicted in Figure a, each Cd1 with a slightly distorted octahedral coordination geometry is six-coordinated by two O atoms (O1 and O1A) from two different L3– ligands and four N atoms (N1, N1A, N3, and N3A) from four distinct bpbd ligands; Cd2 with a distorted octahedral coordination geometry is six-coordinated by three N atoms (N2B, N4C, and N5) from three different bpbd ligands and three O atoms (O6, O7, and O4D) from two distinct L3– ligands.

elements.content: To gain further insight into the structure of 6, it is necessary to simplify the ligands and the metal centers from the topological point of view. From the above description, we can see that Cd1 atoms can be abstracted as a six-connected node which links to two L3– ligands and four bpbd ligands, while Cd2 atoms can be abstracted as a five-connected node. Each L3– ligand can be simplified as a three-connected node, and the bpbd ligand can be considered as a rod. On the basis of this simplification, the overall 3D networks of 6 can be described as a (3,5,6)-connected network with a Schläfli symbol of {4·62}2­{42·610·82·10}­{42·66·82}2 topology (Figure e).

elements.content: According to the above structural description of our title complexes, we find that L3– ligand adopts a variety of coordination modes (), and it is a good candidate for constructing interesting coordination polymers. All of the six complexes have one L3– ligand and one and a half Cd(II) centers, trinuclear cadmium(II) clusters formed through Cd(II) centers and oxygen atoms from carboxylate groups can be found in complexes 1–4 (Figure ). Trimetallic Cd-clusters for complexes 1–3 are linetype, while equilateral triangular Cd-cluster for complex 4. Even though enantiomerically pure (S)-(−)-5-(1-carboxy-ethoxymethyl)-isophthalic acid trisodium salt (Na3L) was employed as the reactant, the products 1, 2, 5, and 6 crystals are centrosymmetric and display mesomeric architectures. This phenomenon has also been previously reported, but the exact reason for the racemization is unclear and remains under investigation. Complexes 3 and 4, in which the helices induced from chiral ligands can be found, display homochiral frameworks.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

According to the above structural description of our title complexes, we find that L3- ligand adopts a variety of coordination modes (), and it is a good candidate for constructing interesting coordination polymers. All of the six complexes have one L3- ligand and one and a half Cd(II) centers, trinuclear cadmium(II) clusters formed through Cd(II) centers and oxygen atoms from carboxylate groups can be found in complexes 1-4 (Figure ). Trimetallic Cd-clusters for complexes 1-3 are linetype, while equilateral triangular Cd-cluster for complex 4. Even though enantiomerically pure (S)-(-)-5-(1-carboxy-ethoxymethyl)-isophthalic acid trisodium salt (Na3L) was employed as the reactant, the products 1, 2, 5, and 6 crystals are centrosymmetric and display mesomeric architectures. This phenomenon has also been previously reported, but the exact reason for the racemization is unclear and remains under investigation. Complexes 3 and 4, in which the helices induced from chiral ligands can be found, display homochiral frameworks.

elements.content: The different structures of the complexes 1–6 with the same metal center of CdII and the same L3–ligand indicate that the N-donor ancillary coligands have a great influence on the structures of the complexes due to their different structures and flexibility. The remarkable difference between the six complexes is that no N-donor ancillary coligand participates in the formation of the complicated 3D structure of 1, while in 2–6, an N-donor ancillary coligand appeared. When the twist N-donor ancillary coligand is induced in 3–6, a 3D structure of 3, 2D structure of 4, 2D structure of 5, and 3D structure of 6 are obtained as a result of the diversity of flexibility and distortion of p-bix, m-bix, dpa, and bpbd. While when the flexibile bpp participates in the formation of 3D structure of 2, [Cd(bpp)] n helical chains with right- and left-handed chirality are obtained.

elements.content: To characterize the complexes in terms of thermal stability, thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of 1–6 were carried out from room temperature to 800 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere (Figure S6, ). All six coordination polymers are quite stable. The framework of 1 begins to collapse above 412 °C. In the case of complex 2, no obvious weight loss was observed until the temperature reached 350 °C, where the framework of the structure began to collapse. The TG curve of 3 displays the first weight loss of 2.98% (calculated, 2.61%) from 30 to 120 °C, corresponding to the loss of one lattice water molecule. A gradual weight loss from 330 °C dictates that the complex was decomposing continuously when the temperature was rising up. The TG curve for 4 shows that no obvious weight loss was observed until the temperature reached 335 °C, indicating that this metal–organic framework material has high thermal stability. For complex 5, a gradual weight loss between 30 and 195 °C is attributed to the release of both the solvated and coordinated water molecules (observed, 5.75%; calculated, 5.40%). A gradual weight loss from 250 °C corresponded to removal of the organic components. As for complex 6, weight loss of two lattice water molecules took place in the range of 60–145 °C (observed, 3.83%; calculated, 3.33%), and the anhydrous component began to decompose at 260 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis and PXRD Patterns

To characterize the complexes in terms of thermal stability, thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of 1-6 were carried out from room temperature to 800 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere (Figure S6, ). All six coordination polymers are quite stable. The framework of 1 begins to collapse above 412 °C. In the case of complex 2, no obvious weight loss was observed until the temperature reached 350 °C, where the framework of the structure began to collapse. The TG curve of 3 displays the first weight loss of 2.98% (calculated, 2.61%) from 30 to 120 °C, corresponding to the loss of one lattice water molecule. A gradual weight loss from 330 °C dictates that the complex was decomposing continuously when the temperature was rising up. The TG curve for 4 shows that no obvious weight loss was observed until the temperature reached 335 °C, indicating that this metal-organic framework material has high thermal stability. For complex 5, a gradual weight loss between 30 and 195 °C is attributed to the release of both the solvated and coordinated water molecules (observed, 5.75%; calculated, 5.40%). A gradual weight loss from 250 °C corresponded to removal of the organic components. As for complex 6, weight loss of two lattice water molecules took place in the range of 60-145 °C (observed, 3.83%; calculated, 3.33%), and the anhydrous component began to decompose at 260 °C.

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was used to check the purity of complexes 1–6 (Figures S7–S12, ). All the peaks displayed in the measured patterns (b) are similar to those in the simulated patterns (a) generated from single-crystal diffraction data, indicating single phases of 2–6 are formed. The differences in intensity may be owing to the preferred orientation of the powder samples. The PXRD for 1 suggests that a single phase of 1 is formed, and it is the major component of the product, but it is not an absolutely phase pure, which may be caused by an unknown impurity.

elements.content: Inorganic–organic hybrid coordination polymers, especially those with d10 metal centers, have been investigated for fluorescence properties and for potential applications as fluorescence-emitting materials, such as light-emitting diodes (LEDs). Therefore, in the present work, the photoluminescence properties of complexes 1–6 as well as the free Na3L ligand were studied in the solid state at room temperature. As shown in Figure , excitation at 350 nm leads to intense blue fluorescent emission bands at 432 nm for 3, 408 nm for 5 and 410 nm for 6, while weaker fluorescence emissions occur at 408 nm for 1, 394 nm for 2, and 418 nm for 4, respectively. Compared to the weak emission peak for free Na3L ligand, the emissions of 3, 5, and 6 with the enhancement of luminescence may be attributed to ligand chelation at the metal center, which effectively increases the rigidity of the ligand and reduces the loss of energy by radiationless decay. Bathochromic shifts of emission occurring in 1, 3, 4, 5, and 6 are possibly assigned to different coordination environments around the metal ions, since photoluminescence behavior is closely associated with the metal center and the ligands coordinated around it. Complexes 1–6 may be suitable as excellent candidates for the exploration of blue-fluorescent materials, since they are highly thermally stable and insoluble in common solvents.
elements.clean_text:
Photochemical Properties

Inorganic-organic hybrid coordination polymers, especially those with d10 metal centers, have been investigated for fluorescence properties and for potential applications as fluorescence-emitting materials, such as light-emitting diodes (LEDs). Therefore, in the present work, the photoluminescence properties of complexes 1-6 as well as the free Na3L ligand were studied in the solid state at room temperature. As shown in Figure , excitation at 350 nm leads to intense blue fluorescent emission bands at 432 nm for 3, 408 nm for 5 and 410 nm for 6, while weaker fluorescence emissions occur at 408 nm for 1, 394 nm for 2, and 418 nm for 4, respectively. Compared to the weak emission peak for free Na3L ligand, the emissions of 3, 5, and 6 with the enhancement of luminescence may be attributed to ligand chelation at the metal center, which effectively increases the rigidity of the ligand and reduces the loss of energy by radiationless decay. Bathochromic shifts of emission occurring in 1, 3, 4, 5, and 6 are possibly assigned to different coordination environments around the metal ions, since photoluminescence behavior is closely associated with the metal center and the ligands coordinated around it. Complexes 1-6 may be suitable as excellent candidates for the exploration of blue-fluorescent materials, since they are highly thermally stable and insoluble in common solvents.

elements.content: Considering that the homochiral complexes 3 and 4 crystallize in the non-centrosymmetric chiral space groups, their solid-state circular dichroism spectra and nonlinear optical properties are investigated. The solid-state circular dichroism spectra of 3 and 4 are recorded on the bulk crystal product with KBr pellets. The CD spectrum of complex 3 exhibits a positive Cotton effect with peak at 261 nm, and a negative Cotton effect around 292 nm (Figure a). The CD spectrum of complex 4 exhibits a positive Cotton effect with peaks at 242 and 297 nm, and a negative Cotton effect around 268 nm (Figure b).

Circular Dichroism and Second-Harmonic Generation Efficiency

Considering that the homochiral complexes 3 and 4 crystallize in the non-centrosymmetric chiral space groups, their solid-state circular dichroism spectra and nonlinear optical properties are investigated. The solid-state circular dichroism spectra of 3 and 4 are recorded on the bulk crystal product with KBr pellets. The CD spectrum of complex 3 exhibits a positive Cotton effect with peak at 261 nm, and a negative Cotton effect around 292 nm (Figure a). The CD spectrum of complex 4 exhibits a positive Cotton effect with peaks at 242 and 297 nm, and a negative Cotton effect around 268 nm (Figure b).

elements.content: In this paper, we have presented of the synthesis, structural characterization, and properties of a series of six cadmium(II) complexes which are based on a new chiral ligand (S)-(−)-5-(1-carboxy-ethoxymethyl)-isophthalic acid trisodium salt (Na3L). The complexes were crystallized with nitrogen heterocycles as coligands except complex 1, which only contains cadmium(II) centers and L3– ligands. Even though enantiomerically pure (S)-Na3L was employed as the reactant, the products 1, 2, 5, and 6 crystals are centrosymmetric and display mesomeric architectures.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In this paper, we have presented of the synthesis, structural characterization, and properties of a series of six cadmium(II) complexes which are based on a new chiral ligand (S)-(-)-5-(1-carboxy-ethoxymethyl)-isophthalic acid trisodium salt (Na3L). The complexes were crystallized with nitrogen heterocycles as coligands except complex 1, which only contains cadmium(II) centers and L3- ligands. Even though enantiomerically pure (S)-Na3L was employed as the reactant, the products 1, 2, 5, and 6 crystals are centrosymmetric and display mesomeric architectures.

elements.content: The combination of the rigid and flexible chiral ligand can be used to obtain diverse networks in different conditions and can be considered as a candidate to design more intriguing architectures. Complexes 1, 2, 3, and 6 possess novel 3D metal–organic networks with different interesting topologies. Complexes 4 and 5 are 2D layered structures, and then formed 3D supramolecular structures through the weak interaction between adjacent layers. Complexes 3 and 4 crystallize in the chiral C2 space group, and their CD spectra exhibit obvious positive or negative Cotton effects. Moreover, 3 and 4 are SHG active, and the SHG efficiency is 0.5 and 0.4 times as much as that of urea, respectively. Future research will further focus on other chirality-related ligands on the coordination assembly.

cln_elements.content:
The ligand (S)-(−)-5-(1-carboxy-ethoxymethyl)-isophthalic acid trisodium salt (Na3L) was synthesized by reaction of 5-bromomethyl-isophthalic acid dimethyl ester with methyl (s)-(−)-lactate (Scheme ). A mixture of 5-bromomethyl-isophthalic acid dimethyl ester (1.43 g, 5 mmol) and (s)-(−)-lactate (1.0 mL, 10 mmol), and Ag2O (1.16 g, 5 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (20 mL) was stirred for 48 h at rt. After filtration, the solution was evaporated under reduced pressure, and the residue was chromatographed on silica gel with CH2Cl2. The ester was dissolved in 15 mL of methanol with stoichiometric CH3ONa and refluxed until the solution turned clear. The reaction mixture was then removed by evaporation, and the resulting off-white solid Na3L was dried under vacuum overnight. Yield: 1.25 g, 75%. Anal. Calcd for C12H9O7Na3 (%): C, 43.13; H, 2.71; found: C, 44.01; H, 2.30. 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO): 8.36 (s, 1H), 8.20 (d, 1H), 7.92 (d, 1H), 4.33 (m, 1H), 3.81 (m, 2H), 1.29(d, 3H). IR/cm–1 (KBr): 3423(vs), 1593(s), 1368(m), 1246(w), 1116(w), 784(w), 721(w).

[Cd<sub>1.5</sub>(L)]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

Complex 1 was synthesized hydrothermally in a Teflon-lined stainless steel container by heating a mixture of (S)-Na3L (0.0167 g, 0.05 mmol) and Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (0.0308 g, 0.10 mmol) in 6 mL of distilled water at 130 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature. Colorless block crystals of 1 were collected and washed with water. Yield: 57% based on cadmium. Anal. Calcd for C24H18Cd3O14 (%): C, 33.23; H, 2.09. Found: C, 33.32; H, 2.21. IR/cm–1 (KBr): 3423(s), 1604(s), 1556(vs), 1452(s), 1377(vs), 1112(m), 1062(w), 1018(w), 909(w), 776(m), 736(m).

[Cd<sub>1.5</sub>(L)(bpp)]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

A mixture of (S)-Na3L (0.0167 g, 0.05 mmol), 1,3-bi(4-pyridyl)­propane (bpp) (0.0100 g, 0.05 mmol), and Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (0.0308 g, 0.10 mmol) in distilled water (6 mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel container, heated at 130 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature. Colorless block-like crystals of 2 were obtained in 64% yield based on cadmium. Anal. Calcd for C50H46Cd3N4O14 (%): C, 47.50; H, 3.67; N, 4.43. Found: C, 47.93; H, 4.02; N, 4.21. IR/cm–1 (KBr): 3440(s), 2908(w), 1614(s), 1560(m), 1427(m), 1368(s), 1285(w), 1229(w), 1158(w), 1128(w), 1070(w), 1018(w), 809(w), 775(w), 725(m).

{[Cd<sub>1.5</sub>(L)(<italic toggle="yes">p</italic>-bix)]·H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

Complex 3 was synthesized in a similar way to that described for 2 except using p-bix (21.0 mg, 0.1 mmol) instead of bpp. Colorless block crystals were isolated and washed by water. Yield: 73% based on cadmium. Anal. Calcd for C52H50Cd3N8O16 (%): C, 45.25; H, 3.65; N, 8.12. Found: C, 45.43; H, 3.91; N, 7.94. IR/cm–1 (KBr): 3441(m), 3112(w), 2924(w), 1620(m), 1553(s), 1451(m), 1370(s), 1285(w), 1242(w), 1110(m), 1022(w), 943(w), 874(w), 850(w), 728(w), 658(w).

Synthesis

Synthesis of Na3L

The ligand (S)-(-)-5-(1-carboxy-ethoxymethyl)-isophthalic acid trisodium salt (Na3L) was synthesized by reaction of 5-bromomethyl-isophthalic acid dimethyl ester with methyl (s)-(-)-lactate (Scheme ). A mixture of 5-bromomethyl-isophthalic acid dimethyl ester (1.43 g, 5 mmol) and (s)-(-)-lactate (1.0 mL, 10 mmol), and Ag2O (1.16 g, 5 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (20 mL) was stirred for 48 h at rt. After filtration, the solution was evaporated under reduced pressure, and the residue was chromatographed on silica gel with CH2Cl2. The ester was dissolved in 15 mL of methanol with stoichiometric CH3ONa and refluxed until the solution turned clear. The reaction mixture was then removed by evaporation, and the resulting off-white solid Na3L was dried under vacuum overnight. Yield: 1.25 g, 75%. Anal. Calcd for C12H9O7Na3 (%): C, 43.13; H, 2.71; found: C, 44.01; H, 2.30. 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO): 8.36 (s, 1H), 8.20 (d, 1H), 7.92 (d, 1H), 4.33 (m, 1H), 3.81 (m, 2H), 1.29(d, 3H). IR/cm-1 (KBr): 3423(vs), 1593(s), 1368(m), 1246(w), 1116(w), 784(w), 721(w).

[Cd1.5(L)] n  (1)

Complex 1 was synthesized hydrothermally in a Teflon-lined stainless steel container by heating a mixture of (S)-Na3L (0.0167 g, 0.05 mmol) and Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (0.0308 g, 0.10 mmol) in 6 mL of distilled water at 130 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature. Colorless block crystals of 1 were collected and washed with water. Yield: 57% based on cadmium. Anal. Calcd for C24H18Cd3O14 (%): C, 33.23; H, 2.09. Found: C, 33.32; H, 2.21. IR/cm-1 (KBr): 3423(s), 1604(s), 1556(vs), 1452(s), 1377(vs), 1112(m), 1062(w), 1018(w), 909(w), 776(m), 736(m).

cln_elements.content:
To characterize the complexes in terms of thermal stability, thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of 1–6 were carried out from room temperature to 800 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere (Figure S6, ). All six coordination polymers are quite stable. The framework of 1 begins to collapse above 412 °C. In the case of complex 2, no obvious weight loss was observed until the temperature reached 350 °C, where the framework of the structure began to collapse. The TG curve of 3 displays the first weight loss of 2.98% (calculated, 2.61%) from 30 to 120 °C, corresponding to the loss of one lattice water molecule. A gradual weight loss from 330 °C dictates that the complex was decomposing continuously when the temperature was rising up. The TG curve for 4 shows that no obvious weight loss was observed until the temperature reached 335 °C, indicating that this metal–organic framework material has high thermal stability. For complex 5, a gradual weight loss between 30 and 195 °C is attributed to the release of both the solvated and coordinated water molecules (observed, 5.75%; calculated, 5.40%). A gradual weight loss from 250 °C corresponded to removal of the organic components. As for complex 6, weight loss of two lattice water molecules took place in the range of 60–145 °C (observed, 3.83%; calculated, 3.33%), and the anhydrous component began to decompose at 260 °C.

Preliminary experimental results show that the bulk material of complexes 3 and 4 display modest powder SHG efficiencies of approximately 0.5 and 0.4 times that of urea respectively, which is about 200 and 160 times higher than that of α-quartz, both of which compare favorably with the values of reported frameworks. They are acentric and may have potential application as nonlinear optical (NLO)-active materials.

Thermal Analysis and PXRD Patterns

To characterize the complexes in terms of thermal stability, thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of 1-6 were carried out from room temperature to 800 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere (Figure S6, ). All six coordination polymers are quite stable. The framework of 1 begins to collapse above 412 °C. In the case of complex 2, no obvious weight loss was observed until the temperature reached 350 °C, where the framework of the structure began to collapse. The TG curve of 3 displays the first weight loss of 2.98% (calculated, 2.61%) from 30 to 120 °C, corresponding to the loss of one lattice water molecule. A gradual weight loss from 330 °C dictates that the complex was decomposing continuously when the temperature was rising up. The TG curve for 4 shows that no obvious weight loss was observed until the temperature reached 335 °C, indicating that this metal-organic framework material has high thermal stability. For complex 5, a gradual weight loss between 30 and 195 °C is attributed to the release of both the solvated and coordinated water molecules (observed, 5.75%; calculated, 5.40%). A gradual weight loss from 250 °C corresponded to removal of the organic components. As for complex 6, weight loss of two lattice water molecules took place in the range of 60-145 °C (observed, 3.83%; calculated, 3.33%), and the anhydrous component began to decompose at 260 °C.

Preliminary experimental results show that the bulk material of complexes 3 and 4 display modest powder SHG efficiencies of approximately 0.5 and 0.4 times that of urea respectively, which is about 200 and 160 times higher than that of α-quartz, both of which compare favorably with the values of reported frameworks. They are acentric and may have potential application as nonlinear optical (NLO)-active materials.
